p.head: An interval of dialogue as song

lg.l: kuṉṟavaruṅ kaṇṭu niṟpak koḻunaṉoṭu koṇṭu pōyiṉār
Saying, ‘In front of us who come, having scared away small birds,
Having chased away parakeets, having gone to the hills, staying [there],
Bathing in the waterfalls, diving into mountain ponds [and now] being perturbed,
Who could you be? — You who are like a creeper/Vaḷḷi [Murukaṉ’s wife],
In the fragrant shade of the mountain kino tree,
You who stood [here], having come, losing a breast so that the mind trembles
Not being angry, [= in a friendly way], she said,
When harsh Karma - having arrived - took shape,
So that the king along with fragrant Maturai were lost,
I am the one of the fast[-acting] Karma that returned,
Having thus lost [my] husband. Upon saying this,
As all the hillspeople stood watching, bowing, fearing,Having put together their opposing hands with twin-bangles in worship,
All celestials showering a long[-lasting] shower of flowers
From within [their own] limits [= from the skies],
She went, being taken along with [her] husband.
Because there is no unique, great god like her for our clan,
Oh you people of the small hamlet! Oh you people of the small hamlet!
Take [her as your] God, oh you people of the small hamlet!
Take the unique God under the good shade of the kino tree of fragrant work,
At the low-hanging mountain [= valley] of Paṟampu
[With] waterfalls that shine [with respect to their] colour,
Oh you people of the small hamlet!
Beat the Toṇṭakam drum. Beat the small Paṟai drum.
Place in [your] mouth the = the conch. Make move the curved bells.
Sing Kuṟiñci. Lift up fragrant incense. Make an offering of flowers.
Stand at the guarded entrances. Revere [her]. Sprinkle a mixture of flowers.
The big mountain will not sleep
For [the sake of] the lady who lost one breast.
Look at one thing over there, oh you with ornate jewels! Here, look at this [thing].
Let us bathe in the mountain waterfall that falls here, having arrived,
Saying it will fall, taking on the beauty of Indra’s bow [= a rainbow]
Emitting the fragrance of pure honey,
As kajal dust, a pleasant power of yellow musk [and]
Let us bathe, o female friend, let us bathe!
Let us bathe in the mountain waterfall
In the groves surrounded by clouds
Of him who is not gracious, having consumed our beauty,
I don’t see a single reason [for] the heart to be vexed
[With] the new floods that come, having rubbed against the stones of his mountain.
We bathed possessed by [= thinking of] whom [else], oh confidante,
Other than [this] new flood that came,
Having rubbed against the stones [of his mountain]?
I don’t see a single reason [for] the heart to be vexed.
Apart from the new flood that came, having played with [= dashed against]
Before whom [else] did we bathe, oh confidante?
I don’t see a single reason [for] the heart to be vexed.
Apart from the new flood that came, having played
Upon whom [else] did we bathe, oh confidante?
If we bathed, having dived deep in the flawless floods,
Let us sing one [song], having linked [together] the Kuravai composition
Having praised [him], [he] having lifted up the spear
That killed the strong mango tree [in] the waters;
Isn’t [this] the spear in the hand of the Lord
Who does not leave Centil abundant in excellence,
It is the very leaf[-tipped], white[-hot] spear
That on a former day, cut off the mango tree [that was] Cūr,
Having entered into the rocky, dark ocean!
Isn’t [this] the spear that was lifted by him who possessed
Without a duplicate, six beautiful faces and twelve hands?
It is the white[-hot] spear that killed [all] opposition
So that the kings of the sky that was blue [with respect to] colour
In which the greatness of demon perish - praised,
Isn’t [this] the spear in the brilliant hand
Of him who drank the sacred breastmilk
[From] the six mothers, [in] the flowered sleeping chamber
It is the long spear that killed, having split open
The chest of the Acura with an advancing discus [and] staff/rod
[In] the hill [with] the name of the wader bird (krauñca).

p.head: An interval of song (revealing the truth).

lg.l: Oh good girl with bangles [at the] joints! This has become a joke!
In order to alleviate the pain that was caused
By him from the cool mountain slopes on which black pepper grows,
Mother, who was indeed unknowing that it was
Him with [a garland of] blossoming Kaṭampa flowers,
She, desiring the Veṟi dance, said, ‘Oh man with the spear (Murukaṉ priest), may you come!’
Oh good girl with choice bangles! This has become a joke!
If the man with the spear (Murukaṉ priest) who comes
In order to alleviate the pain of the man from the great mountain,
[Really] does come, he is a fool!
He who killed the hill [with] the name of the wader bird
Oh good girl [with] hands [with] close-set bangles! This has become a joke.
The man with the spear (Murukaṉ priest) that comes
In order to alleviate the pain [on account] of him of the mountain fragrant with perfume
[That] man with the spear (Murukaṉ priest) is a fool. More than even him,
If the son of the man who dwells under the banyan tree comes,
Oh good girl with fine jewels! It seems a joke.
[About] the man with the spear (Murukaṉ priest) who comes
In order to alleviate my pain given by
More than him - [That] man with the spear (Murukaṉ priest) who comes
My God with a garland of Kaṭampa [of] the rainy season is fool
On which the eminent man with the spear (Murukaṉ priest) comes,
The son of him who dwells under the banyan tree
Along with [her with] fine jewels, upon the blue bird (peacock),
We need/may request the marriage celebration!
Oh Lord, the son of the Lord in the good Kayilai mountain!
We worship your sacred feet that resemble the pretty blossoms of the full Aśoka tree,
[Along with] the naïve daughter of the mountain people,
[With] a [crescent-]moon forehead [and] the nature of a peacock [= Vaḷḷi],
Among those who speak [of] the union in the neighbourhood,
Oh Lord [who is] the son of the daughter of the mountain [Pārvatī]!
We worship your pair of feet, Lord who is lofty [in your] state,
[Along with] the girl of the hillspeople that stay in the mountains of their clan,
Saying, ‘They will experience a union known to many’!
We worship the pair of feet of one man with six faces
Along with the girl of our clan - that girl [who is] the girl of the hillspeople
Saying ‘May those who touch your sacred feet of yours,
Atop the [sacred] ghat, obtain a good union -
A union of letting go of sins!’
I went before him who would depart [soon] -
The man of the mountain lands [with] a perfumed, pretty chaplet,
[He] having deigned to hear, standing hidden/in secret [the songs we sang],
[And], I stood, having worshipped [with my] hands his sacred feet.
Pray, listen, oh friend, to that which was narrated!
Having worn Kadamba flowers, holding up a spear,
This town did not understand [your] coming
Due to the matters of a girl
There were no six faces; there was no beautiful peacock;
There was no [Tēvaiyāṉai with] close-set shoulders.
There was no woman from the hills;
Indeed, the people of this hamlet are ignorant!
As I narrated the result of the ways of gossip,
The man of the mountains with blossoms who went away,
Turning his back with a dry, fading heart,
Let us sing one thing on the state in which
The celestials and their relations, having come together
Revealed to the Pattiṉi [wife] whom many worship,
The beloved hero of she who fashioned/created the taking
Of great Maturai with a breast!
Pray come, friend - we shall sing!
Pray come, friend - we shall sing!
We shall sing, praising her who brought order with fire
To Kūṭal with bannered, storeyed houses
So that the order of the king left.
When we sing, praising her who brought order with fire,
We wish/pray for the marriage celebration
Of the man from the big mountain!
She will worship, having praised, the woman Pattiṉi:
One [girl with] the labia [like] a [cobra’s] opening hood
Is indeed in our fresh fields!
Even after the celestials had given, having led
The husband of [her with] labia like a [cobra’s] opening hood,
They did not cease in [their] words [of praise]!
As the immortals with a life in the skies worshipped and praised [her],
There is a lady - she who is under the fragrant kino tree of the forest.
She who is under the fragrant kino tree of the forest
Certainly is not one to return with her husband
As we sing, praising she who does not return,
May this town too obtain a boon!
[But] there is a boon! There is a boon!
Indeed, this town has a boon
To see the union [between] the husband
And the lady with gold bracelets.
Having seen the Kuravai which is danced, singing on the state [of things],
Endlessly eating and delighting on an unending day.
May the king of the western people
Who ruled Kolli along with the Himalaya upon which a bow was drawn
